attachments.text: Any programming language is exactly Python, is Python. That is a tautology, a statement which is true because it states something is what it is. (That’s not the definition of a tautology, but all statements of that form are tautologies.) So, the a...

elements.text: This sounds familiar, a short mentioning of Julia is there already.

text:
> Any programming language is exactly Python, is Python. That is a tautology, a statement which is true because it states something is what it is. (That’s not the definition of a tautology, but all statements of that form are tautologies.)
OMG I hate such answers. Pretentious in multiple ways. Everyone knows what a tautology is, especially someone who is asking such a question. Also, you are flexing your language muscle while completely disregarding flexibility of language use.

elements.text: Any programming language is exactly Python, is Python. That is a tautology, a statement which is true because it states something is what it is. (That’s not the definition of a tautology, but all statements of that form are tautologies.)

OMG I hate such answers. Pretentious in multiple ways. Everyone knows what a tautology is, especially someone who is asking such a question. Also, you are flexing your language muscle while completely disregarding flexibility of language use.

text: The entire answer he's going on a tangent, including assuming things about the OP (like, "stop worrying about speed when you don't have a working program", and he then goes on to say "BUT you may find out you need to optimize..." - hence the question, dummy!). That's just Quora. No filters.

text: I have not looked at quora in a long time. It was all the rage when I was in uni. I knew our local quora celebrities. I was actually happy that something substantive like a Q&A site is generating celebrities (minor ones, but still). Now the question is has the quality dropped in the last 5 years or my standards have gone up

text: No, it's just really bad. Anyone can setup an account, say they are X or Y, and pretend to know what they are talking about. For all the hate StackExchange gets, at least it's reliable and informative.
